job_title: Academic Program Manager in Madison, WI
pros: There is no denying that the UW-Madison is a reputable institution. I feel pride telling people I work here and people are always impressed. We're part of the Wisconsin Retirement System which is one of (if not THE) leaders in state pension programs. People who are passionate about education could definitely feel fulfilled working at this institution and there are countless opportunities to move around campus in different roles, allowing for growth and development.
cons: There is an expectation for employees to be highly educated, but the pay is very, very poor for employees in staff roles. If you're looking at a faculty position, you will likely find that the pay is more in line with industry trends and other Big Ten institutions. It's incredibly difficult to get a job here without a minimum of a master's degree, but your salary will likely not align with your education. The issue of pay for staff members has been brought up to leadership before and they state that they realize staff are under paid, but that this is a trend nationwide so there is an overall acceptance to normalize underpaying employees. In addition, it can be challenging to advance since campus has lots of people with PhDs. There is an assumption that people with PhDs are automatically leaders and this is very rarely true since PhDs are typically focused on research, not leadership. As a result, jobs that would typically require a bachelor's degree (master's at a maximum) end up going to people with PhDs. In addition, despite a multiyear, multimillion dollar effort, title and pay across campus lacks equity. In one program, an employee may be called a Director, but a person in another program who does the exact same work could be called an Advisor or a Specialist. Raises are also almost entirely non-existent so the only way to really advance in position and/or pay is to move into new roles, which can be tricky because of the issue(s) previously indicated. Sadly, there is truly no benefit to doing your job well year after year in the same position since this will ultimately stunt any type of economic mobility.

review_title: Be Selective About Which Dept to Work For
pros:
• Especially for those looking for something new, new to the field, or are not sure what they want to specialize in, there are many different job opportunities in one place.
• If you stay 5+ years, the PTO and Sick time are tough to match anywhere else, especially if you are banking any of it. You won't lose your PTO/Sick time if you move to another department.
• There are some areas that are stable with low-turnover with very reasonable work-life balance options such as majority work from home, flexible hours, etc. (It is just more difficult to get into these areas because there is low-turn over...)
• If you use the Metro, the bus pass for employees is inexpensive and a great option.
• If you enjoy the focus of supporting students, you will find many positions that will fulfill that goal and give you that feeling of purpose you are looking for, directly or indirectly. A number of positions work with student employees.
cons:
• Pay is better in the private sector. Sometimes significantly. Do not expect regular raises. Merit raises are rare if they are given out at all depending the area you work for. At best every year or two there is a 2% raise set up by the university, but it will never outpace or get near meeting inflation. Getting a new position is a more effective way of getting a raise.
• Turnover is VERY high in some areas and is usually a sign of poor management or unmet employee needs. Often, areas state being understaffed is the source of their problems and that filling the empty seats will solve everything - ignoring WHY people are leaving. If interviewing with a department and there is high turnover, ask them why the turnover is happening and what their long-term plans are for addressing this. Ask them what their plans for training are if the dept is short-staffed. Do NOT ignore this red flag.
• The "Peter Principle" is notable. "Management" is not seen as a separate skill and these positions are often given to individuals who are skilled in their area but not with running operations or managing people.
• Many departments are still majority (non-remote) on-site work and will not consider remote even if they are not customer-facing or student-teaching positions requiring in-person work. 
• Some areas did not adjust to covid-era needs well. Some are not-remote not because the work itself requires the employee to be on-site, but because management does not have the skills to communicate and coordinate with a remote workforce. Campus switched their financial processes to a largely online system, a change has been resisted by some.
•Parking on campus is expensive.
• Regarding diversity, the campus makes notable steps toward addressing visible diversity, but neurodiversity and less visible disabilities are very under-addressed, varying by dept. Autism, ADHD, visual vs audible learners, and more are not as well supported if not (unintentionally) prevented from reasonable jobs.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Madison, WI
pros:
Get to work with some of the smartest people around. The research done at the CS department is very interesting. Also the CS department is highly rated (12-13th in the nation overall). 

The professors are all very good at what they do and by and large personable. All the students, with very few exceptions, that I interacted with were courteous, respectful and dedicated.
cons:
Disorganized department due to very rapid growth in the past few years. The hours are long. The graduate TA contract is for an average of 20 hours a week but expect to work 30-40 hours a week at times, unless you one of the lucky graduate teaching assistants to assist for a seminar, very experienced or naturally very fast. (Also, the average is not 20 hours a week, it is more. It is a common concern.) 

Undergraduate TAs are treated way better as they get paid by the hour instead of a salary. Professors for budget reasons are careful how much work they assign to undergraduate TAs. Some professors are mindful of the hours the graduate TAs put in and don't abuse their TAs, but I don't believe it is the norm. Keep in mind long hours seven days a week is the norm for academia, so most professors do not consider what they put graduate TAs through to be abuse. Most professors are genuinely positive people. It is the system, and like fish in the sea they no longer are very aware of the water they swim in. They are adapted to it.

I suggest getting a MS degree, not a Ph.D. and not being a TA, unless you aspire to be a professor. This way one graduates sooner and can start earning real money. Yes, paying for tuition and not working is costly, but if one graduates a year sooner one will make up the loss very quickly and come out ahead.

pros:
-Good health insurance
-Opportunity to work with researchers and take part in world-changing projects
-The job itself is amazing and rewarding - which makes all of the "Con's" all the more tragic.
cons:
-The turnover at the UW Madison IRB's has been astronomical. Exit interviews show that it is due to the awful work environment, with many people taking lower-paid jobs just to escape. Despite this, no effort has been put into improving the situation, which has been ongoing for many years.
-Toxic, abusive, unskilled, ineffective managers 
-Gaslighting and abuse by management as well as lack of employee support by HR is recognized by ombuds and academic staff governance but is so deeply embedded that there isn't much that can be done about it. There are lots of policies about maintaining a professional workplace environment and ensuring fair treatment of employees, and lots of procedures for reporting problems, but little to no structure for actually addressing the problems. Employees have spent a lot of time and effort genuinely trying to solve problems to no positive end.
-People who report problems are punished; you can report that you were disciplined for reporting problems (which is a violation of policy), but as above, nothing is done to solve the problem
-Lots of favoritism resulting in unfair employee treatment (for promotion opportunities, special projects, salaries, etc.)
-Little opportunity for advancement - lots of opportunities to learn more/do more, but little incentive since monetary or title increases are hard to come by.

review_title: A once great University in Decay
pros:
All my coworkers and direct manager are great to work with.
Being around and doing infrastructure work to support research is rewarding on its own.
The benefits are better than the private sector - PTO and insurance.
cons:
UW Madison has a huge bureaucracy. So many Deputy Vice Chancellors of blah blah... My dept has almost 30 managers.
Admin is too focused on EID. Constant emails on the issue. I've never seen the issues here on campus but the admin is obsessed with it. But I do have a concern about my future here a slightly conservative WSM.
UW not spending enough on the buildings and equipment. Obsolete gear everywhere in old buildings, 70+ year old infrastructure I can't believe it still works sometimes.
COVID Concerns - the drool tests don't seem safe. Having 40 people drooling without masks in a single room every week- really come on!?
Furloughs.
Shortage of trades-people.
Raises seem to be inflation level only.

review_title: A university built into the city around it [Graduate Student]
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros:
Working as a graduate researcher will of course vary heavily based upon program and advisor, so I will stick to generalities. UW-Madison and the city around it are heavily inter-related. The city is great, and offers many of the conveniences of a large city with a small city feel. There is a large outdoor culture in Madison that permeates the university, and most of the student body seems to like being out and about. There is a strong culture at UW based around the lakes, especially concentrated around memorial terrace (it even serves beer!) This makes finding common events and spaces easy. 

 I've always had good (though limited) interactions with administration. The libraries are well stocked, and I have rarely not been able to find a research article I've needed in some form or another. New research facilities at the hospital have revitalized many labs on campus, pulling them out of basements in brick buildings. UW-Madison also boasts many helpful resources when it comes to entrepreneurship and patent law in the form of the Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation (WARF). The Wisconsin Idea means that the university is heavily involved in the surrounding area. University presence in the form of education and research is easy to see and easy to get involved in.
cons:
Drinking culture is a large part of Wisconsin, and the university is no exception. Though this has its benefits, but roving bands of drunk undergraduate students can get tiresome. 

Conservative leadership in the state's government is beginning to turn against the university, forcing them to tighten budgets, so the future of the university's growth might be somewhat uncertain.

job_title: Middle School Tutor in Madison, WI
pros: The hours were great; a couple hours a day four days a week. Hours were only in the afternoon and so you were never going to get up on a morning or late night shift and there wasn't the hassle of having to find someone to cover your shift. There were many middle school tutors so supervisors were able to compensate for absences either due to exam schedule or being out sick. The kids were for the most part easy to work with. There were a few that didn't want to do their work or participate in daily lessons but they weren't any significant behavioral issues or anyone too rude.
cons: The supervisor was ridiculous. He would give long winded speeches about making sure the kids were academically engaged all the time. Before this supervisor the rule was that if the kids got through the daily work sheet, were up to date on their homework, and had their folders and binders organized they had free time. Many read books, some played cards, some played board games etc. This supervisor thought cards and board games were not engaging. The kids should study for up coming tests or review old test was his grand plan. Their middle school students. They went to school for 8 hours and tutoring for two hours. I think twenty minutes of playing cards is not going to tank their potential or academic aptitude.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Madison, WI
pros: The university is a unique place to work.  Lots of resources for research are available in core facilities.  There is a wide range of expertise on campus.  The healthcare benefits for state employees are fairly comprehensive and reasonably priced.
cons:
Post-docs are often not paid according to NIH standards and the salaries vary widely from lab to lab.  Many post-docs only receive a "raise" if they get their own fellowship money.  If you do have your own fellowship money, you are not officially considered a university employee, so they won't even deduct the taxes from your paycheck (you have to do it yourself, and they don't tell you that) and you lose a few other employee benefits.  Once your fellowship money runs out, your salary remains constant so you quickly end up being paid below NIH standards once again.  All of this indicates that postdocs have few protections and their experience and technical skills are not appreciated.

The campus is very spread out and different departments are housed in different buildings, which makes networking outside your department very difficult,.

review_title: Fun, crazy and excitement outside of work. Normal work for lower pay.
pros:
Great city to work in. It's a college campus so there are always things going on (sports are the most talked about). Even the Madison community are smart people and they do hard work and know how to enjoy themselves. A mid-sized city dominated by the university means that people will talk about similar events happening around.
As for working for the University of Wisconsin-Madison, their environment is really good (spacious and good views out the window), and if you are into cutting edge research, depending on your field, this could be haven for you. There are always conferences/symposiums and such that occur almost every month.
cons:
As a mid-sized city, it doesn't have many places to go: being in the mid-west, you almost need to have a car to get around - side note: there is a bus system. The other downside is that it's a college campus that prides itself in sports (which is what the students WILL talk about), which means it can be boring for those who don't follow their sports.
Regarding working at the university, the downsides include lower pay, and you don't get stipends or bonuses (at least if you're not that important). Professors don't even have much budget to send people to go to conferences.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: You can work from home if you request so
cons: Overwork; poor benefits; poor feedback; low salary.

job_title: Financial Specialist III in Madison, WI
pros: The campus is beautiful, and employees are welcome to nearly all of the campus-hosted events; everything from music festivals to movie nights. The atmosphere in most departments is relaxed, and even professional staff rarely dress in full business professional attire. Departments may grant work schedule flexibility, and some offer telecommuting on a limited basis. Leave benefits are generous; sick leave and vacation leave are separated so illness does not affect your vacation plans. Leave benefits also include personal days. Healthcare premiums are extremely low ($86 per month for a single person) and medical care in the area is world-class.
cons: STAGNANT. There is no clear way to advance through the system, and even more than that, there doesn't seem to be much desire for advancement within the general workforce. There is a laughably low level accountability, and business processes haven't changed in decades. No one is working towards innovation because the pay here is so ridiculously low. There is no such thing as a raise, regardless of what your job performance is. Granted, they offer all of their employees a living wage (to my knowledge), but this is a world-class university that brings in $6 billion a year in research revenue.

review_title: A great institution, bogged down by state politics
job_title: Information Processing Consultant in Madison, WI
pros:
Pros:

- Great health care benefits (although these have been shrinking and shrinking due to state politics)
- Emphasis on work/life balance, at least in the group where I worked
- Opportunities to take on new responsibilities and learn new skills on-the-job
- Many training opportunities, including the option to take a work-related class at UW-Madison and get reimbursed
cons:
Cons:

- Lower salaries than the private sector
- Opportunities for advancement are based on funding availability, which the state government is not providing right now.
- 1% cost of living raises instead of real raises in most cases, unless you move to a new job title (as mentioned above, dependent on funding)
- Because people who are the most skilled often don't receive promotions or additional compensation, you will often encounter people who do the absolute minimum.
- Decisions are often based on university politics rather

review_title: For incoming graduate students and researchers
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros:
1) The graduate programs in Chemical & Biological Engineering (CBE), Biochemistry (IPiB), College of Agricultural & Life Sciences (CALS), Computer Sciences (esp PMP & Computer architecture specialization) are reputed nationally for the high impact research done here and the availability of infrastructure to support cutting edge research. 

2) WARF (Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation) is among the oldest and most successful technology transfer offices in the nation. As the designated patent and licensing organization for UW–Madison, WARF advances transformative discoveries to the marketplace to benefit humankind across the world. This has in turn generated huge revenues to support various research and entrepreneurial programs campus wide.

3) The university has various specialized research centers or think tanks (such as Great Lakes Bioenergy Research Center, UW-Carbonne cancer center, Wisconsin Energy Institute etc) to catalyze collaboration across departments to address grand challenges in their core areas.

4) Madison is a calm city with several opportunities for water sports and has been consistently ranked the best city for biking. Being the capital of Wisconsin state, its undoubtedly famous for various cheese based products and  beer.
cons: Madison has a rough weather - cold and windy for almost 6-7 months in a year.

pros:
- Relaxed environment
- Great work/home balance (point of emphasis)
- Overall, nice people to work with
- Benefits are really nice (vacation, retirement, healthcare)
- Most groups have opportunity for continued education (conferences, classes, etc)
cons:
- Salary is low to middle of the road
- Extremely hard to get rid of low-performers
- Slow to adopt new technologies (still afraid of "the cloud")
- Could use better develop->test->deploy processes 
- Some decisions are really opaque to people impacted most
- Subject to political environment (impacted by decisions at State level)
- On-boarding process can vary widely, but overall is pretty poor
- For a technology organization, there are some folks who don't really understand technology very well
- Recently removed the ability for a technologist to work overtime and use those hours later in the year (now have to be used within 2 weeks of earning)

review_title: It's hard for people new to the system
job_title: University Services Associate II in Madison, WI
pros: It is a very nice university.  Most of the people on campus are nice because it is a state university, most people are laid back.  There are many training opportunities on campus, and if you dig, there are also many activities for employees.  The perks include a discounted membership to the gyms, bus pass at a very low price and an annual bike pass for just $20.  The benefits are better than the average private companies.
cons: If you are new to the system, you are most likely going to start at the minimum wage for the pay grade.  Although I had a bachelor's degree, when I started in 2010, it was my first year in the state system.  So I was paid the minimum wage of the pay grade.  It is until I got promoted that I finally got a raise.  This job is for somebody who just needs to bring in a couple thousand a month to compliment the family income.  Can't rely on this solely to raise a family.  I am barely making it with a family of one.

review_title: Great place to be a young biological graduate student to learn and grow,
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: There are a lot of positives about working at  UW-Madison. There is a low-cost of living and very welcoming place to live. One of the greatest things is that so many graduate students have external hobbies outside of lab and it is encouraged by many of the grad school. Many of the researchers are eager to mentor new graduate students. With a plethora of interesting cutting edge projects and world class researchers, this is a great place to be trained as a scientist
cons: This is a very large open university and many of the research buildings are spread out. One of the biggest down fall is the large partying/drinking culture surrounding UW-Madison.  Sometimes you can feel left out if you do not drink in excess or like a undergrad. Also because of current state budget cuts by Scott Walker in the last two years, we have seen a decrease in stipends.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros:
-Great Research (you can get published in top tier journals if you get the right project)
-Opportunities to gain technical skills that will be valued by private industry
-Decent salary by graduate student standards, and you won't have to be a TA to get funding
cons:
-terrible work-life balance
-competitive work environment (although there are collaborations among labs, students within the same lab will have to compete for the best projects)
-Many students do not complete their PhD. Those who do have trouble finding positions where they would be compensated for having a PhD.
-I've heard that the campus is a great social environment, but I was so busy working that I did not experience it.

review_title: Graduate Student/Graduate Assistant in the Humanities
pros:
-You'll get a free education
-You get to teach talented students
-Good benefits
-You'll make enough to live a 'grad student life'
-There are multiple sources of funding if you take the time to look for them
cons:
-It's a long-term investment to be a grad student. If it doesn't pay off, you've sunk a lot of years and wasted some potential income.
-Low pay. Enough for a 'grad student life' isn't enough to have a family without your spouse working. And for the amount of money I bring in to the university by teaching undergrads, I'm woefully under-compensated.
-Benefits are worsening: in light of Walker's plans, it's beginning to get more costly for insurance. It's still fine, but it's much worse than it was even three years ago.
-The job market is horrible in the Humanities. So bear that in mind with my first con.

review_title: Might be ok for starting your career - but don't get stuck there
pros:
Your experience will depend completely on the school/division and department that you work for.  Overall pros include:
* It's a big place, with new job openings every day, so there is lots of room to move up and laterally.
* The Union/Terrace - great place to chill and have meetings
* Pretty good benefits (although they used to be better)
* Good place to start your career
cons: UW suffers every year from budget cuts, so there is not as much stability as there used to be, salaries are not competitive, and benefits have been cut.  Also - I'd give it low marks on diversity and cultural competency.

review_title: Many hardworking and dedicated professionals; a culture of blame.
pros: The students are inspirational. Certain faculty members are dedicated to the education and development of young people as well as cutting-edge and creative research.
cons: Clashes with the legislature, executive (governor), and voters create fictitious and unnecessarily hostile budget crises and other controversies. Campus leadership has changed so often in the past decade that no accountability or real progress has been possible. Some ineffective staff and faculty keep "jobs for life" while others are barred from advancing, as salaries and benefits wane to the point of being non-competitive with peer institutions.

pros: I have the ability to make new connections in my field and expand on my current techniques in the field of molecular biology and aquaculture with shrimp
cons: I have had to work months straight without a day off. The opportunities of going to conferences have been non-existent. The treatment I have received being a female in the science industry, even as a student has been appalling. I have been discriminated against due to the fact I am a woman in STEM.

review_title: Good Place to Get a PhD
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: It is a highly ranked engineering school in a nice town. While the campus is large (and so is the size of the student body), the graduate student environment is more personable and inviting. There are numerous professional development workshops and seminars to further graduate student's careers.
cons: The admittance to the graduate school is not transparent. You must meet the minimum requirements for the department before being admitted, even if you know a faculty member will sponsor you. Because of this, I believe many students do not choose to attend UW-Madison because the school either waits to long to extend official offers or never gives applicants a final decision.

review_title: Vibrant Exciting Enviroment, but underappreciating employer
pros:
Getting to work alongside some of the most brilliant people in my field of study
Broad freedoms over work time and pursuits
Very nice location (on the shore of Lake Mendota)
cons:
1) Relatively low salary that has been trending lower for the last 7 years...due in equal parts to shift of benefits costs to employees, "voluntary" pay reductions needed to balance department budget, elimination of earned merit raises.  This is due to the extremely icy relationship between the University and the state government.
2) very slow actions with regards to chaned

pros:
A large, public university that contributes a lot to the community, state and country in terms of scientific research, humanities, agriculture, art and literature.

Despite weak, ineffectual senior leadership, enough good people show up everyday and make the university "happen!"

Beautiful location in a wonderful city.
cons:
Generally weak, self-centered leadership from the Associate Dean level & up. Leadership is totally out of touch with the everyday workings of the university. Students' welfare and academic progress are irrelevant to leadership.

Pay is poor. Local tech college pays better for equivalent positions.

review_title: Depends where you are - different cultures in each division
job_title: Chemist, Lab Manager in Madison, WI
pros: Provides opportunities to college students that they won't get anywhere else, good grievance policies to help protect employees from unfair practices, HR is very helpful if you reach to them (I had to reach past my division HR but it was worth it).
cons: Take full advantage of students willing to work without getting paid, not a ton of upward progression, managers don't know the rules and depend on HR (great if HR knows the answers too), culture is very student based on campus and very "all the old guys are buddies" with bad management off campus. Pay isn't great especially for the incredibly technical tasks that scientists do.

review_title: Good people trying to do good work.
job_title: Student Hourly Technical Service Representative in Madison, WI
pros:
They were knowledgeable of their respective fields.
They would work to find info not on hand, or to reach the goal that was requested.
Each group was very personable and outgoing.
cons:
Um... How do I put this?  This is academia, the knowledgeable ones are getting on elderly, and most never really knew computers in their youth or as they developed.  As the former tech support, my experience had more to do with holding hands and fostering trust that the machine won't explode.  Okay, that's harsh, but my job was to make the computers work.
Odd politics between member groups and the Division.  Just something that kept my head low and unconcerned

review_title: Only professors have it good, lab managers and techs are invisible and second class citizens.
pros: Great job if you don't want to do anything except support a professor and his/her students. Usually the lab positions are not terribly stressful.  Okay training for other tech positions in other companies depending on the skillset you can learn.  But, many companies don't want people whose experience comes from academia.
cons: Low compensation.  You will never get credit for any innovative ideas because the professor will take it or give it to his students.  You are and always will be low person on the totem pole and made to feel that way.  I've worked here many years and I know it is a mistake to continue, but my skillset is not terribly useful outside my current lab.  Basically, I'm trapped in a dead end low wage job.

review_title: High morale even with the bureaucracy
pros: I worked at UW Madison from 2007-2008 and I felt that the vast majority of staff and faculty were very professional and skilled in their work.  Departmental leadership really carries a great deal of responsibility and the new Chair with whom I worked made it her mission to inspire enthusiasm and energy into everyone's work.  She was a skilled researcher and professor herself so she set a great example.
cons: The school is very large and so there are many levels of bureaucracy which seemed to fragment staff from faculty while I was there.  Of course staff are there to support faculty but it seemed that the two entities really didn't communicate much with each other outside of the needs of the job.

review_title: Time demands well beyond what we were told to expect
job_title: Teaching Assistant/Faculty Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Many of the professors you work under impart excellent teaching methods to the TAs and FAs working under them. They cared about students and their assistants and tried to help any way they could.
cons: I was actually last here in 2011, but UW needs to be held accountable for the demands put on TAs and FAs. With a 50% appointment, TAs are told to expect to work 20 hours a week. However, if they're to do a good job (which is vital to the students they're teaching), they work far more hours than that. And the evaluations assistants receive at the end of the semester can be very important to the employee's career. So if the assistant puts in only the bare minimum of 20 hours, they are likely to get poor evaluations.

review_title: It used to be great here...
job_title: Senior Research Specialist in Madison, WI
pros: The work hours are flexible and as of now we are still granted plenty of sick leave and vacation time, which is great for raising a family and work/life balance.  Health insurance coverage is good.
cons: For low to mid-level employees, the pay is not good.  Raises are minimal or non-existent  and they don't come very often, even for employees with outstanding yearly reviews, because they are limited by bureaucracy.  Opportunities for career advancement for my type of position are very limited.  Plan on paying at least $700/year out of your own pocket to park your vehicle if you drive to work.

review_title: Only pays to work here if you are in administration.
pros:
Flexible schedule

Good work life balance
cons:
Low pay for the science staff that keeps the University research enterprise running. 

The top faculty have left or are leaving. Can't attract new top faculty to replace them. 

A new HR system that only rewards administrative staff, ensuring they are paid market wages while those actually fulfilling the written mission of the university are paid half as much. 

Science and research arm of University is likely to collapse soon simply because they refuse to pay fair wages to scientific staff, which prevents retention of good staff or ability to attract new high quality staff. 

Way too much emphasis placed on diversity issues. There are far more important factors that will cripple the institution faster.

pros: Very Flexibile schedule, vast and good education opportunities, decent benefits, lots of collaboration between groups, good people with lots of intelligent folks around always willing to help
cons: Low pay, few raises, benefits being eroded, parking cost is high, raises go to administrative staff and hr people resulting in significant pay inequity for Research staff who are required to run a gauntlet of paperwork designed by the admin and hr folks making pay raises near impossible.

review_title: Great place for a student to prepare for work-world
pros:
As a student employee, I was able to get a taste of a number of projects within a number of teams. 
I also learned how to schedule, plan, and debrief meetings, update laptops and manage equipment that was accessible to all employees in the department. 
I shared an office, and had my own computer, as well as printer.
My boss always let me take time off to concentrate on school 
I got to choose my own schedule based on my school schedule.
cons: I was the youngest employee and found it hard to relate at times - but my coworkers were always nice and seemed interested in my life outside work nonetheless

pros: The university is a big institution so it all depends on in which department/unit/center you work. I worked in a center in the College of Education and had a good experience. Interesting work, good colleagues, good work-life balance and great benefits.
cons: Universities tend to have some more "extreme" employees, some bad (diva-like tenured professors & long-time administrators skilled in avoiding work and playing the system) and some  good (highly motivated young professors & students). It's sometimes challenging to deal with that. Also, the bureaucracy can sometimes be stifling. If you are impatient, don't work here.

review_title: Beautiful place to work, good balance
pros: Professional colleagues. Cutting edge research. Fantastic facilities. Great biking and walking nearby.  Great benefits including reduced cost bus passes, great health care, world-class retirement system.
cons: Ceiling on advancement depending on your degree.  Once you hit a certain level there are no more steps up and no more raises.  Consistent about punishing employees for supervisors behavious (i.e. if your supervisor does not complete your annual review, you are the one who cannot get a raise or be eligible for bonuses.)  Parking costs are outrageous and if there's a game, it literally costs you to come to work on Saturday.

pros:
I'd worked in the State system for 15 years and earned 6 weeks vacation.
Doing programmatic, organizational work appeals to me.
cons: I experienced ridiculously inappropriate conduct on behalf of professors and high ranking managers.  The lore around it being a fiefdom is not a myth... it is true in each of the three departments I worked in.  Things people were allowed to get away with would be unheard of in the private sector...  the bullying and mistreatment of support staff, unfair conduct, and the unwillingness for high ranks to take ownership for their own stuff that is causing issues in the workplace and then not being held accountable..it is pervasive.  People who arrived at their high ranks by being completely inappropriate with conduct not befitting a high ranking academic staff professional.

pros: The UW Madison campus is very inspiring - the work that happens there is ground breaking in multiple disciplines. The environment of learning is exciting, and there are countless opportunities for professional development or personal interest exploration.
cons: The recent political climate made UW Madison a challenging place to be. News articles question the function and leadership regularly, and there is a somewhat adversarial relationship between the campus and the rest of the state. Education is being devalued in the state, and that is very disheartening.

pros: Great hours. Earliest shifts start at 7:00 AM and are optional, with most interviewers starting at 9:00 AM and latest you are expected to stay is 9:30 PM. Optional to stay until 11:00 PM. Flexible scheduling as well.
cons: It is extremely repetitive and draws on your patience when people are constantly rejecting you and refusing to participate in surveys. There are multiple surveys available which helps out with this as certain surveys people will participate in more than others. Also it can be very difficult to convince someone over the phone that you are not a telemarketer trying to get their money.

pros: Excellent benefits and PTO policy. Most of campus takes mental health very seriously and encourages time off/flex time. Current chancellor is a hard worker and passionate about what she does. Campus cares about their workers and is trying very hard to avoid layoffs during COVID.
cons: Antiquated policies. Campus is massive and often slow to react. People can have vastly different employment experiences based on the management of their division. Grad students, like at a lot of other higher ed institutions, are poorly paid and overworked. Some employees are grossly overcompensated while others are definitely under-compensated.

review_title: UW-Madison is a great place to get a degree
pros: One of the real pros of UW is it's location in Madison. If you are in life sciences research, you will be well placed to interact with the medium sized biotech community of Madison. At the University itself, there is a highly collaborative atmosphere that I found very useful. For those looking to begin a postdoctoral fellowship at UW, there is now a postdoctoral association that offers professional development seminars.
cons: Faculty salaries aren't as competitive as one might expect.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: You get full tuition remission of your graduate tuition fees if you get a total of 33% or higher position as a teaching assistant.
cons: Although assigned to be a 20hr/ week job, you may end up putting in ~30 hrs in some work weeks, especially when grading is involved, and it can be challenging to manage your graduate studies with that workload.

pros: I worked in the Continuing Studies Department and absolutely loved it there. As a student worker, I had the opportunity to explore a lot of different career fields because the department employs many different instructors and program coordinators for various workshops, classes, certificate programs, conferences of all sorts. People here are exceptionally kind and very skilled in their field of expertise. Though there are lots to do, the environment is not fast past and overwhelming. It's a healthy working environment and quite professional. Also, their scheduling is very flexible. They were so willing to work around my schedule.
cons: There were some days that were a bit monotonous, doing a lot of data entry or filing or crunching numbers. But any work has their own cons.

review_title: Excellent in term of opportunity, poor salary
pros: This is one of the best research universities in the world. So you get wonderful research environment. SO many world class professors.  Madison is the best city to live in USA. No doubt. You will love downtown and state street. You c
cons: low salary as graduate student. I know salary of graduate student is low everywhere. But it is just too low here. Quite impossible to lead a normal life. People try to get out of the university after masters just because of the low salary. And worst, you have to pay a huge segregated fee each semester despite the poor salary.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros:
- Good quality to  research with large degree of freedom
- Multiple opportunities for career development (workshops, conferences,  small grants, outreach,...)
- Good writing center to help with writing in English
- On-campus lake with one of the oldest sailing club in US ( can do sail/windsurf after work)
cons:
- Long list of possible course is in fact shorter (thought every other year or faculty left/died)
- There are faculty bullying the students and nothing can be done because they publish a lot
- International students pay 1/3 more of segregated fees than US nationals
- My PhD program wasn't prepared to handle students with health problems
- The university has student diversity problems
- People weren't very sociable after work

pros: Excellent benefits, worthy mission, many accomplished colleagues. The small team within the department nurturing a new and much needed program into existence worked very well together and made significant progress.
cons: Morale within the department very poor, attributable in large part to very poor leadership with dictatorial tendencies and inadequate people skills. Perceptions of uneven treatment and opportunities for advancement detrimental to functioning. These assessments apply to only one department in a very large organization.

review_title: Good coworkers, good benefits, low pay, hard to advance.
pros: Great coworkers with amazing attitudes and work ethics. The benefits we receive are very good. It can be easy to get your foot in the door by taking a state test or accepting an LTE position.
cons: The pay is lower than it would be if you worked in private industry. Hard to impossible to negotiate what you are paid if you are a Classified employee. Hard to advance, even if your department wants you to, the system makes it nearly impossible.

pros: Good training environment.  Flexible hours.  A large group of staff to choose from to choose to work for in my department (Biochemistry).  Large number of seminar opportunities to attend if you so desire.
cons: Outside of academic track research most of the staff has little knowledge of other paths of advancement.  After you choose a lab, you are in part at the mercy of your PI if you did not choose well you can permenently hurt your career.

pros: State of the Art facilities, open collaboration within and between different departments and within the university.  Close interactions between researchers and clinicians, and access to clinical samples.
cons: There is some oversight lacking here and across the country when it comes to expectations for both the student and the mentor for graduate students.  This is no different at UW and some additional structure and oversight, as is relates to hours, mentor responsibilities, among other things, would be helpful.

job_title: Senior Financial Specialist in Madison, WI
pros: 1 pay increase (thanks to the UW Office of Human Resources), learned a lot of financial experience. Good benefits.
cons: I worked at UW Veterinary Care @ UW Madison.  My supervisor played favorites with my only other coworker. All the veterinarians and doctors you work for, think they are better than you and treat you like you're at the bottom. My only coworker I shared an office with, was always cranky.  Unappreciated.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Madison, WI
pros: Huge research campus, lots of resources, big community, great town.  A lot of your experience will vary from lab to lab, department to department - my lab focuses on ambitious, high profile work, competitive funding, etc.  Good career training.
cons: It takes a lot of commitment - I commonly put in 60-70 hour weeks, and working every day of the week (and weekend) is expected.  I imagine that more relaxed research environments exist at UW, but my lab is not one of them.  This is good for my career, but probably sub-optimal for my short-term mental health.

review_title: for graduate RAs in ECE: great place to do research, keep in mind when you want to graduate
job_title: Computer Lab Attendant in Madison, WI
pros:
(1) department leadership team cares about students and are willing to meet and make changes to current dept . policy
(2) department staff are highly efficient and helpful 
(3) active graduate student association provides networking opportunities
cons:
(1) poor work-life balance
(2) no clear graduate requirement from the departement, and neither from some PIs. you will be on yourself in order to graduate on time.

pros: The managers at the Rathskeller worked around my class schedule and ensured I would have adequate work and study time. A majority of the employees were other students so the work atmosphere was very fun. The employees also get to choose their available days and hours every month so you are able to switch it up.
cons: The only con that I can think of is the hot days that one must endure throughout the summer months at the brat stand.

pros:
- Excellent work life balance in many staff and faculty associate positions at the university
- Higher education can be more purpose driven as you're working to help the next generation
- Casual work environment, with students interjecting an energy and dynamism to it.
cons: Coming from the corporate environment the university  on a relative basis seems to lack work accountability in several positions; has less strong leaders and managers in more senior level positions,; and, not every college has a clear strategic plan

review_title: A great place for graduate students to work
pros: In my experience as a TA with graduate students, I found the professors I've been working with to be very respectful of my time as a student first. I never felt over-burdened with TA duties, and the students were equally respectful.
cons: The administrative team in my department is a bit lacking with communication. We often get very short notice in regards to training sessions and job postings.

job_title: University Services Program Associate in Madison, WI
pros: Great people and a great flagship institution of higher learning.  Inspiring.
cons: Pay for "classified" staff (Hourly employees) is very low.  No ability to get raises or a promotion without taking a new position entirely.  Very rigid in ensuring that your job duties stay within those of your job description.

pros: Good overall culture, nice people in a fun city, lots of interesting research going on in the university
cons: Low pay (no surprise there), not much mobility between jobs within the UW system, some positions have little/no chance for advancement, might have to jump through some hoops to get a job if you're not a student

pros: UW in general has great health and benefits packages and the school of medicine and public health employs all sorts of individuals. The UW hospital and clinics campus is an exciting one to work in, and you're surrounded by fantastic research.
cons: My biggest complaint is that it can be hard to land one of these jobs since the university hiring system must mandatorily post all jobs publicly even if they're already 100% decided on an internal candidate. Sometimes you apply to a job, it takes four months to make a decision, and it turned out you never had a shot to begin with.

pros: I'm working with the professor. The working environment is nice and I can feel that I'm getting better and better at the new task the professor assigns to me. If you are a uw-madison student, you should  definetely contact the professors who have taught your major courses before, there are plenty of research and part-time opportunities.
cons: So far so good. The salary is not compepitive compared to off-campus jobs but I learned a lot from this job so it makes even.

pros: Autonomy of work, reputation of UW, pride in institution. Resources are adequate for the size of campus. Lots of research and achievement come out of UW- sometimes we would learn about the great work at out of town meetings.
cons: Turnover, some staff are cynical because of the changes from the governor. If they're that unhappy they should leave versus staying & creating a negative work environment for new hires. The city of Madison is interesting- many elite/ snobby hipsters that aren't welcoming to transplants. Alcohol is celebrated here- this gets old fast.

review_title: Various undergrad research positions and Environmental Resources Center; good employer
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: I've worked with several professors and departments within UW (such as the Environmental Resources Center through UW-CALS and UW-Extension), and how they manage their hourly system is smooth and uniform. Professors do a good job of communicating with you and working around your class schedule, as did the ERC.
cons: Not too many cons, really. And it also depends on the professor or department you work for. Some professors can be hard to reach by e-mail or are not as good at giving direction. The work at the ERC is very self-directed, so know that that's something you like/want.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Madison, WI
pros:
Women's Health.
Fantastic and driven Department Chair.
State benefits with good health insurance and vacation.
Amazing research and physicians to work with.
cons: Inexperienced managers and little support for the new managers. UW is providing a training course for new leadership/managers. I believe the course is offering poor advice on how to be an effective supervisor. Also, obtaining a raise in the University system is quite difficult.

review_title: Professional (Non-Student) Staff at the Division of Continuing Studies (DCS)
pros: So much PTO! Over 20 paid days off per year, not including sick time. Good health insurance. (As far as I know, this is standard across the university for 12-month academic staff.) DCS has a very strong professional development culture - lots of opportunities for learning. Depending on your specific position and unit within DCS, there's interesting work, and opportunities to work on high-profile projects around the university. Many DCS staff get to work interesting cross-functional roles where you get a unique perspective on the organization and opportunities to build connections around campus. Generally friendly and supportive work environment. It seems like Dean Russell is good at getting DCS a "seat at the table" -- it seems like he advocates for us to be involved in campus priorities, which leads to the benefits for staff noted above (though it can also come with some challenges as we coordinate efforts over which we do not have direct authority).
cons: Overall at UW-Madison everything is *extremely* decentralized, and coming from the private sector I have been unpleasantly surprised by how little common feeling there is around the idea of a shared UW-Madison purpose or goals or mission. People might be loyal to their specific unit but there's not much overriding commitment to the entire institution, which I think is detrimental (leads to lack of trust/poor communication/turf wars between units). At DCS there has been a lot of rapid change which isn't necessarily well-managed. At DCS and on campus there is relatively high turnover and a lot of folks moving around internally (this can be one of the only ways to get a promotion/pay raise, in this era of lean budgets around campus). DCS is hiring extremely rapidly without a lot of clear direction and I don't think enough care is being taken to be strategic with this growth. It seems like historically there's been tension between units in DCS that are doing more traditional continuing studies type work (noncredit, adult learners, professional development, etc.) and those working on the more entrepreneurial/for-credit programs, and upper leadership isn't very sensitive about this divide. A lot could be done more efficiently if people were better at communicating internally.

pros: Great people, campus and boss. I love my job and the people I work with. I never want to miss work since it's a joy to be there.
cons: Very large campus, takes a long time to get anything changed. Campus HR is slow to react. Parking is horrible, it's almost $1000 a year and more if you want a ramp. Parking around campus and walking it sucks.

pros: Beautiful campus, UW offers a lot of on-campus training events for staff, good work atmosphere (in my current office), good benefits and Madison is a great city. It is easy to be proud of working at UW-Madison.
cons: Pay is lower than in private sector, some departments are really unpleasant places to work, and being made out to be a worthless parasite by some of the state politicians is a bummer. Since UW is such a large institution, it can take way longer than one thinks it should to get anything done….too many layers at times!

review_title: Graduate Student, Research Assistant, and Teaching Assistant at the University of Wisconsin, Madison.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant, Teaching Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Good people.  Beautiful city.  Nice campus. Greatest Graduate Student/TA union in the country.   Fairly responsive and fair HR system.  Strong scientific history with world class scholars, world class equipment and world class library system.  Opportunities for interdisciplinary research abound.
cons: Pay scales are low.  Diversity is a challenge for UW.  The state government is not fully supportive of the Universities mission.

pros: Friendly, intelligent people.  Working for a good cause.  Stimulating, positive environment.  Even with recent cuts, it still has a good benefits package.
cons: As would be expected, the pay is lower than in the corporate sector.  It is a very large institution with different ways of doing things that  can require a steeper learning curve than other places of employment.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: This is a great university, and the payment is sufficient to cover living cost. The city is small and fun with good safety and friendly neighborhood. Great people to work with as well.
cons: On the downside, it is usually more than two hour's drive to any small tourism sites. Shopping in the Madison area is also not the greatest (Chicago is three hours away). The state is cutting funding from the university.

review_title: Student Research Assistant (WIMR - Med. Phys. and Radiology)
pros: Flexible hours, okay pay (10/hour), great experience (both research and professional environment), great connections, many opportunities to work on teams, work alone, and publish and present results
cons: No overtime, no wage increases, PI rarely told me when he was out of the office, can spend hours working on a task that could be solved in 5 minutes with assistance from PI, can sometimes have little to work on

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Madison, WI
pros: Excellent atmosphere for research and routine life.    The campus is filled with the awesome Infrastructure such as MS, NMRs, HPLCs etc and have so many opportunities for internal and external collaborations & discussion.  Very positive and energetic working environment coupled with an ambitious supervisor.   One of the Best city as far as public transportation is concerned and also so many places to eat outside.
cons: Winter might be pretty cold if you're NOT used to snow.

review_title: Great location and benefits, mediocre pay
pros: Benefits (health and vacation) are great, research is top-notch, great city, laid-back work environment. I can only speak as a full-time researcher in biological sciences, but the infrastructure for research here is amazing.
cons: Employee compensation is poor, career advancement/training resources provided primarily to students and not early career professionals. As with other large universities, lots of red tape.

job_title: IS Tech Serv Professor in Madison, WI
pros: The university's benefits package is nice including retirement match after 5 years of service, coworkers are friendly, the campus is warm and welcoming. Work life balance is fair.
cons: Most jobs available are project positions (4 years), so to stay with the university, you have to shuffle departments every few years. No other cons that I can think of.

pros: It's great to work for the University in this capacity. You get excellent benefits and quite a bit of support including tuition remission.
cons: Conditions can vary widely from position to position with the same title. A project assistantship can be anything from some focused data entry to being the manager of an entire program.

pros: A lot of opportunities to work on projects you might not see in the private sector and at often a massive scale. Working as an IT Professional here can be challenging due to constant budget pressures, but well positioned projects can still find funding. You will find some really smart and motivated folks here.
cons: Pay and benefits have been stagnant or declining for over a decade. A fairly collapsed progression structure, combined with a lack of opportunity for merit raises or cost of living adjustments means that the only real way to see a pay increase is to switch jobs frequently.

pros: PEOPLE Program was a great place to work. They were flexible with student hours. The pay was good and the job was fun. I felt as though I was making a difference.
cons: Sometimes the hours were not as we were told. There was some confusion over school schedules.  I wish we had been paid for travel time because the cabs were often late to pick us up.

review_title: World class institution for academic research
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Madison, WI
pros: UW-Madison has fantastic facilities for chemistry research.  The faculty and staff are supportive and helpful and leaders in their fields.  The career resources exclusive to the department are phenomenal.  Seminar series brings in thought leaders from around the world.
cons: The state of Wisconsin's education funding crisis seems to be driving faculty members away.  It hasn't had a huge effect on the department since I've been here (about a year), but if it persists it could have a damaging effect on the UW status as a leader of science and innovation.

review_title: May be, may be not - opportunities for overall growth of the employee.
pros:
Great place, expertise in many areas. Accessibility to expertise from different fields of study, when in need of a second expert opinion or advice. 
Excellent, seven star rating for library and reference system. 
Easy access and availability to facilities, with latest technology for experimentation, in and around campus. 
High population of young students, help maintain a positive zest in the university town. 
Summers offers plenty of activities in and around the town, not very expensive, not overcrowded and there is no wasted time in traffic jam. 
Limited university housing availability for staff. 
Excellent public transportation.
cons:
Most of the research programs are run with NIH grants of PIs and the powerful PIs have near invincible status. 
Postdoctoral scholars are at the bottom or not eligible for most benefits, lack access to most of the university services and salaries not at par with NIH. 
Internal assistance programs need major overhaul. Lack of independent external review processes to improve, detect & solve issues for employees. 
Lack of active inter-department interactions, such as colloquium, presentations etc. 
Childcare for women employees are insufficient.

review_title: Overall, I've had an excellent experience working at UW-Madison
job_title: Senior Student Services Coordinator in Madison, WI
pros: I've had some flexibility in my weekly schedule, I've been able to do a lot of networking across campus, and in general the majority of the other staff are great to work with in my experience.
cons: There's a pretty established bureaucracy and political element to the way things are run; some of the policies and procedures are antiquated, and UW-Madison has a reputation for paying lower-wages/salaries compared to institutions in other states.

pros: Flexible work-life balance. Conditions of your work are entirely dependent on your department and faculty. However, respect for Teaching Assistants, their rights and time, is fairly widespread. Healthcare is good.
cons: TA wages were among the lowest in the nation a few years ago, as the TA union lost its power under former Gov. Walker. Grad student sill must pay fees around $650 per semester, and more for international students. Wages are enough to live a meager lifestyle in Madison, if not go into debt. Summers are especially hard without external funding. However, wages are steadily improving.

review_title: UW-Madison has a lot to offer, especially if you Madison is your kind of town
pros: Madison is a great place to live, with a number of amenities of a larger city in a medium sized city. The campus culture is lively, Madison is a pretty place to live, and inexpensive when compared to larger Midwestern cities.
cons: The University of Wisconsin - Madison is a fairly bureaucratic place, where decision making is opaque, and rules appear unequally enforced. Diversity is not immediately obvious at the University, as it is comprised largely of folks from the state (which is not particularly diverse).

pros: They are very flexible with scheduling and they work with you during busy times. The employees are all very intelligent and helpful.
cons: At times their is not enough work to do and it can be boring. The office is not efficiently managed all the time. Sometimes it is unclear what is expected of me as an employee.

review_title: Great University and work environment. Difficult academic track.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Madison, WI
pros:
One of the top research universities in the world.
Work/family/life flexibility is unsurpassed
Decent benefits, though were better prior to 2010
cons:
Academics is a long, tough slog. This isn't a knock on UW, or any university, just the nature of the career path.
Pay is average to below average compared to similar institutions.
Salary gets stuck/frozen with frequently only option to gain more is to jump around to similar positions across campus.

review_title: Flexible, great benefits but a lot of workplace politics
pros: You get a ton of vacation and sick days and pretty good benefits.  Work days are flexible with occasional ability to work from home.  Working on campus has a great energy and you are surrounded by bright co-workers.
cons: So many office politics to deal with.  Work, pay, etc is mostly based on time served and job title, not skills and abilities.  Seems like the lifers get stuck in this mentality of "we do it this way because this is how it's always been done".

pros: Excellent location, fun small- midsized midwestern city. High availability of collaborative opportunities. Many excellent researchers and staff, both technical and administrative. Well respected benefits plan is nice, with state funded retirement plan.
cons:
Typical university environment, high emphasis on credentials without marketable skills development. Salary points are low, as expected for state universities. 
Expectation of ridiculous hours in my position without work to accomplish lead to resentment and overwhelming desire to leave.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Of course I can only speak to my experiences with CALS and the Department of Biochemistry. The work-life balance of UW-Madison employees seems more balanced than other academic spots. This seems to be the attitude across campus in my and other academic positions. There are plenty of resources and opportunities for those who seek, but promotions and internal work benefits are obviously dependent on the position and hierarchy of the department.
cons: No real cons that are general to the School. If you don't like the cold, this might be a problem.

review_title: Student lab assistant in the physics department.
pros: Make your own hours, can scale back hours during busy test/homework weeks, projects are diverse and interesting, get to work with graduate students and get a feel for academic research.
cons: Guidance for personal projects can be unclear.  Professors are sometimes too busy to address your needs and questions, which can be frustrating.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: I work as a chemistry assistant in Chemistry department. All the faculty and staff are very friendly and helpful. The advisor is nice. The research is fabulous!
cons: Some people say that winter is too long. But compared to how great it is, the cons are trivial. No other cons in my mind.

review_title: Good environment despite pressure from  State Legislature
pros: Madison is a vibrant community, and the University is filled with forward-thinking professionals.  In my experience, academic departments tend to foster creativity and cutting edge research.
cons: Salaries are lower than average.  There is constant pressure from the Wisconsin State Legislature to cut budgets, which translates to salary cuts in the form of increased employee burden for health insurance, retirement etc.  Raises are non-existent and almost solely in the form of retention packages offered if faculty get offers from competing schools.

pros: Very flexible and they know you are a student and that is the priority so that is very nice. I enjoyed it alot and everyone is really nice. It sucks serving food but pays very well for a student job.
cons: I someetimes and to take on a lot more than I can handle. I mean it makes you stronger, but it would be nice if there were other supervisors

job_title: University Services Associate in Madison, WI
pros: Working for a world class university can be rewarding. Many of the people at the UW are first class and hard workers.
cons: There is a problem with classist attitude between Faculty and non-academic employees. But the number one problem is the current Governor of Wisconsin and his cohorts at the capital. By cutting funding they are seriously hurting a Great University. By political meddling, they are killing the ideals of untrammeled sifting and winnowing the UW is internationally known for.

review_title: Passionate staff from assistants to members of the Chancellor's Executive Board, I worked with people who truly cared.
pros: The good-natured, committed staff at UW is a great reason to work here. I always felt fully supported and backed up by my colleagues.
cons: Not much to say here. Some outdated facilities and technology including slow printers and lots of construction and remodeling creating annoyances at times.

pros: Great benefits, great pay, awesome work environment. They pay for my tuition to go to school. Overall a pretty great company.
cons: Sometimes the doctors don't like to listen to nurses even when they are breaking policies such as handwashing and catheter associated infection initiative. There are many people to communicate with for each patient and sometimes communication is not as fluid as it should be.

pros: The department has access to many core facilities and is expanding resources to eventually include cryo-EM. It also has several departmental functions per year and is generally well-funded in terms of graduate programs and student support.
cons: The bureaucracy, politics, and nature of the academics in the department is revealed in its total lack of diversity. I have never met so many two-faced, poor communicators in my professional career, which infiltrates the student culture. Too many professors are using outdated methods and offering less mentorship and expertise to their lab members and new faculty.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Nice campus, good city for college and grad students, grad students from ECE have the opportunity to take courses out of their departments which helps expanding knowledge.
cons: a few retired professors work slow and have old and obsolete instruments in their labs that no one has touched within past years.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Incredible Benefits Package and wonderful atmosphere & co-workers. The offices and available equipment and machinery are well kept and are readily available for research.
cons:
Depending on the department, there may be a fair amount of red tape when it comes to anything spending related. 
Office politics seem to dominate certain aspects of the job.

review_title: Overall, I had a great time in Madison
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: The research was great and the professor I am working with is the best mentor I have ever had.  I have learned so much from him and I have become a very competent research over the years.
cons: It is pretty standard as far as graduate student employment goes, but the pay and benefits are probably not as good as they should be, especially with the recent explosion in housing demand here in Madison.  Thanks to Scott Walker's cuts, this will probably not get better.

review_title: Graduate Assistantship at UW Madison ECE Dept
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros:
- Strong connection to companies
- flexibility to take time off to pursue internships
- strong grad student / young professional community in Madison
- Highly collaborative research
- excellent health insurance coverage
- low cost of living in city
cons:
- Until recent pay increase, pay was low compared to other grad institutions
- high cost of segregated fees with no remission
- Winter is really cold

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Madison, WI
pros: The Madison campus has a great research environment with a lot of on campus collaborations. There are also collaborations with the local scientific industry sector.
cons: Wisconsin winters can be very cold, difficult to balance work/home life with long working hours. There really is not a lot of negative things to say about the University and city of Madison.

pros: Plenty of opportunities to develop and work with supervisors. Managers are more than willing to train interns in the accounting software used on a daily basis.
cons: Due to intern turn over it is difficult to build a culture of progress when the intern staff is replaced every semester or year. It is harder as well to be trained quickly when your supervisors are dealing with a large workload and there are no other senior interns to help with training.

review_title: Tolerable Experience for Entry-Level/Students, Classic Government Employee Downsides for Full-Timers.
pros:
- Great pay for entry-level positions.
- Many positions available that emphasize schedule flexibility for students.
- Multiple promotion routes for many positions.
- Standard fantastic state-benefits for full-timers.
cons:
- Not incredibly competitive in terms of salaried employment, but the benefits make up for it if you can get them.
- The usual bureaucratic nonsense and managerial bloat that is consistent throughout most state institutions.
- Dealing with the fractured HR structure is a nightmare if you need a direct answer regarding a policy for your department.

review_title: Wisconsin is cold, so does the school feel to me...
pros: It is a big school with a lot of intelligent students and professors.
cons: The administration is so bureaucratic! As an international student,  I needed some help on my tax return. The pay roll office, international student service, and my department office pushed me to each other, without offering any useful help. Even worse, the pay roll office once replied to me on the phone that "we can too many of Asians on campus", and cannot help every single one of you!"

review_title: Easy, but not so challenging or friendly
pros: Student employees receive lots of flexibility and freedom. Easy place to work with low expectations. Good for someone who is juggling lots of other things.
cons: Not much room to grow without influential connections. Some of the IT related areas seem like students forgot that the frat party ended the night before. Lots of sexually charged "humor" and male camaraderie - good for those who fit the stereotype, not so much for those who don't. Management was either unaware or intentionally uninvolved.

review_title: Great supervisors, very kind and they let you put your studies first but still work at least 16 hours a week.
pros: There are flexible hours, good supervisors, and relatively high pay.  Everyone is a student, so they're all in the same boat as you.
cons: It's hard work that's sometimes gross, and there are no night shifts available.  Cleaning bathrooms isn't exactly glamorous, but hey, it's money.

review_title: Good learning opportunities, low pay and opportunity for minorities and women
pros: Great learning opportunities, if you proactively seek them out and make a strong case for attending them. to your supervisor.
cons: Few advancement opportunities for women and people of color, very difficult to be offered positions at the director level.  Lots of discussion and talk on engagement, diversity, and inclusion efforts, very little authentic activity surrounding these topics.  Engagement is inauthentic at best, regularly microagressive and damaging when efforts are carried out and in day-to-day operations.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: The working conditions as a TA are decent. Tuition remission is the best part of the deal. The students are generally bright and decently motivated. I enjoyed working with my fellow grad students.
cons: The general pay is not great. Madison is increasingly expensive, and the stipend is not really enough to live off very easily. You are always subject to the whims of faculty, who can be out of it and unreasonable. Public support for higher ed in Wisconsin seems to be going down the drain.

review_title: Flexible, great benefits, plenty of opportunities to learn and grow
pros: Progressive attitudes. The culture allows you to think outside of the box and try new ideas without fear of losing your job if something you try doesn't work out.
cons: Lack of accountability in most of the positions you encounter can slow down processes and lead to frustration when trying to get things accomplished that may be "difficult". Too politically correct to address certain issues that need addressing.

review_title: Great gig. Wish it could have been permanent.
pros: The intellectual community was both stimulating and supportive. I learned so much from my peers and colleagues. I felt enriched daily by their knowledge. I very much enjoyed teaching at UW-Madison. My students were committed and intellectually rigorous.  All in all, a very positive experience.
cons: I struggled to establish good working relationship with my mentor. I also wish I felt more integrated into my home department, but, perhaps, that is just the nature of temporary, non-tenure track academic employment...?

review_title: Good Old Boys Club for some, Demoralizing for others
pros: There's pockets of great research and teaching and outreach, it's a beautiful, huge and diverse campus, Madison is a great place to live.
cons: Silos, silos, silos.  Bloated, know-nothing, hired-from-within administrators in many areas.  Leadership vacuum, vision isn't communicated, talent isn't cultivated.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: This is a wonderful graduate school to be a part of from a community standpoint. Students are well supported and I had no problems finding a research assistant position. Many graduate students have children. Benefits are very good.
cons: This review is department-dependent, as expected. There is some, but not a lot of cross-department communication. More communication would benefit students, particularly those looking for research positions.

pros: I would say this is really fantastic position. Besides, great location, neighbors, people, and so and so. Salary is good. Benefits are also good.
cons: I cannot find many to complaint. Maybe,  a bit beaurocratic? But this is natural to any university across the world. maybe too cold in winter?

job_title: Resident Physician, Family Medicine in Madison, WI
pros: High volume of obstetrics and inpatient experiences with good variety and range of acuity.  ICU experience helps with identifying critically ill patients.
cons: Large system that sometimes increases administrative burden. Can be difficult to work with specialists. Program spans 3 hospitals with different version of the same EMR, which can make switching rotations difficult.

review_title: A good place to work as graduate student
pros:
Very strong academic research ranking in most of its disciplines. There are students from all over the world so you will not feel lonely.
The city is nice too, very beautiful. Every time when I travel to other cities for business, I will miss Madison.
cons:
Long winter with snow. If you are OK with that (but most time in room), there is no complain.
This is a public university. Due ti the poor economy, it funding has been reduced.

pros:
Very close working environment, get the opportunity to work with a diverse range of incoming students.
Build public speaking experience with daily presentations.
cons: The pay is obviously not ideal, but is fair given that it is a University sponsored job. It is not a good job if you can not multitask, and cater to the needs of others.

pros: At UW Madison, you get to make your own hours. The department I work in is very laid back. They let me take on my own projects that spark my interest.
cons: I work in the Biochem Building and it's dangerously close to QQ Express. I eat there all the time but I get to eat at my desk so I guess that's cool. The pay isn't great but it's better experience than most of the jobs I can get with my background.
